The distinction between triggers and vulnerabilities is helpful in that it allows us   to better understand why the factors that are often cited as touching off the crisis seem   disproportionate to the magnitude of the financial and economic reaction.  Consider   subprime mortgages, on which many popular accounts of the crisis focus.    Contemporaneous data indicated that the total quantity of subprime mortgages   outstanding in 2007 was well less than $1 trillion; some more-recent accounts place the   figure somewhat higher.  In absolute terms, of course, the potential for losses on these   loans was large--on the order of hundreds of billions of dollars.  However, judged in   relation to the size of global financial markets, aggregate exposures to subprime   mortgages were quite modest.  By way of comparison, it is not especially uncommon for   one day’s paper losses in global stock markets to exceed the losses on subprime   mortgages suffered during the entire crisis, without obvious ill effect on market   functioning or on the economy.  Thus, losses on subprime mortgages can plausibly   account for the massive reaction seen during the crisis only insofar as they interacted with   other factors--more fundamental vulnerabilities--that served to amplify their effects.       On the surface, the puzzle of disproportionate cause and effect seems somewhat   less stark if one takes the boom and bust in the U.S. housing market as the trigger of the   crisis, as the paper gains and losses associated with the swing in house prices were many   times the losses associated directly with subprime loans.
